thread.title: Widow of slain St. Louis County officer invited to D.C. for president's speech to Congress
thread.title_full: Widow of slain St. Louis County officer invited to D.C. for president's speech to Congress

author: Joe Holleman St. Louis Post-Dispatch
title: Widow of slain St. Louis County officer invited to D.C. for president's speech to Congress
text:
Close J.B. Forbes 
Elizabeth Snyder walks back to the car with her brother, Officer Justin Sparks, at Valhalla Memorial Park in Godfrey, Ill., on Thursday, Oct. 13, 2016, at the conclusion of the grave-side service for Snyder's husband, Blake Snyder. Snyder was shot and killed while investigating a disturbance in the Green Park neighborhood. Hundreds of police officers from around the region and the country attended the funeral. Photo by J.B. Forbes, Widow of slain St. Louis County officer invited to D.C. for president's speech to Congress By Joe Holleman St. Louis Post-Dispatch Feb 22, 2017 ( … ) J.B. Forbes 
Elizabeth Snyder walks back to the car with her brother, Officer Justin Sparks, at Valhalla Memorial Park in Godfrey, Ill., on Thursday, Oct. 13, 2016, at the conclusion of the grave-side service for Snyder's husband, Blake Snyder. Snyder was shot and killed while investigating a disturbance in the Green Park neighborhood. Hundreds of police officers from around the region and the country attended the funeral. Photo by J.B. Forbes, jforbes@post-dispatch.com TownNews.com Content Exchange 
The wife of a fallen St. Louis County police officer will be in the nation's capital Tuesday to listen to President Donald Trump address a joint session of Congress. 
Elizabeth Snyder posted earlier this week on Facebook that she has been invited to sit in on the address in the House of Representatives chambers. 
"I'm completely honored and cannot wait to hear what our president has in store, especially for law enforcement," Snyder wrote. 
Snyder is the widow of Blake Snyder, a 33-year-old police officer who was shot to death in October while on a domestic disturbance call in south St. Louis County. 
Trenton Forster, 18, has been charged with first-degree murder, second-degree assault and two counts of armed criminal action in connection with the shooting. 
Joe Holleman • 314-340-8254
